awd_titl_txt: SaTC: CORE: Small: The Blurring of Non-essential Notifications and Critical Security Warnings: Examining the Problem of Generalization in the Brain
awd_abstract_narration:
This project measures how decreased attention to frequent software notifications negatively influences peoples' responses to uncommon security warnings that are truly critical. The researchers will use eye tracking equipment to examine this problem by measuring attention to notifications and warnings through eye gaze patterns, and individuals' decisions in response to these messages. They will observe how changes occur in the context of a single computing device, such as a laptop computer, as well as diminished attention across devices, such as how frequent notifications on a mobile device affect people's responses to uncommon security warnings on a desktop computer.

Through a series of laboratory experiments using eye tracking and functional Magnetic Resonance Imaging (fMRI) technologies, the researchers will examine the conditions under which habituation to frequent software notifications generalizes, or carries over, to uncommon security warnings. These conditions include the similarity of visual appearance and mode of interaction (i.e., look and feel) between notifications and warnings, the volume of notifications, and whether these factors cause generalization to occur across devices. They also examine how people behaviorally respond successfully to security warnings by adhering to the warning recommendations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit:

Users’ failure to heed security warnings is an important problem in cybersecurity because warnings are often the last defense standing between the user and compromise. A primary cause of this failure is habituation, which is diminished attention because of frequent exposure to warnings. However, Previous research has hinted at the problem of generalization but has not directly examined it. 
This project makes the following principal contributions:

1. Determine the conditions under which generalization occurs.

Our results in this study show that habituation occurs not only for single warnings, but also to whole classes of notifications that share similar characteristics. As a result, users may already be deeply habituated to a security warning that they have never seen before simply because it is similar to frequent notifications. 

Further, because generalization of habituation is fundamentally a neural phenomenon, this project measured it both neurally (via fMRI) and behaviorally (via observation in field experiments).

2. Develop security warnings that are resistant to generalization.

Using the insights gained above, we developed and tested warning designs that are resistant to generalization in the following ways:

a. Visual similarity between software notifications and security warnings contributes greatly to generalization of habituation. Changing the visual appearance of a warning to differentiate it from standard software notifications reduces the occurrence of generalization of habituation.

b. Changing the way people interact with a security warning so that it is different from the mode of interaction for common software notifications. We demonstrate that this can also substantially decrease the occurrence of generalization. Further, we show that this effect is distinct from changing the visual appearance of a warning.

Broader impacts:

With the increasing number of notifications in our lives across a range of mobile, Internet of Things, and computing devices, the accumulated effect of generalization is likely substantial, lessening the effectiveness of comparatively rare security warnings that are truly critical.

This project developed warning designs that mitigate this problem and makes these designs publicly available to allow implementation in a wide range of software products, thereby enhancing the security of individuals throughout society. Specifically, this study gives practitioners two levers to reduce the degree to which habituation to frequent software notifications carries over to rare security warnings:

  1. Changing the appearance of warnings so to be distinct from frequent notifications from applications and the operating system.
  2. Changing the mode of interaction of warnings so to be distinct from frequent notifications from applications and the operating system.

By using either or both of these techniques, practitioners will be able to substantially reduce the degree to which people ignore warnings because of their similarity to frequent non-security-related notifications.


We provided a mentored environment for graduate students. These students were cross-disciplinary, from neuroscience and psychology, to business and information systems. We had student collaboration on all aspects of research, including design, experimentation, data analysis, writing, and presenting at conferences. 

This type of interaction has been proven to be beneficial to introducing students to the world of academic research and accompanying professional societies and meetings. The experience that students gained through this project helped prepare them for success in their future graduate programs and careers and thus provided a lasting impact on these students’ professional development. 

The results of the research were disseminated through multidisciplinary conferences on decision neuroscience and information systems. Some specific conferences include Symposium on Usable Privacy and Security (SOUPS), the Cognitive Neuroscience Society annual meeting, and the NeuroIS Retreat. We also shared relevant findings in courses on information security and neuroscience at Temple University and Brigham Young University. Finally, the results are publicly available via the web at neurosecurity.byu.edu.
